บริษัท Metaplanet ของญี่ปุ่นยืนยันว่าจะยังคงสะสม Bitcoin ต่อไปแม้จะเผชิญกับตลาดที่ฝืดเคืองซึ่งส่งผลกระทบอย่างหนักต่อราคาหุ้นของบริษัท CEO Simon Gerovich กล่าวว่าบริษัทจะซื้อสกุลเงินดิจิทัลนี้ต่อไปและขยายรายได้ โดยไม่ใส่ใจว่าราคาหุ้นของพวกเขาได้ดิ่งลงมากกว่า 63% ในรอบ 6 เดือนที่ผ่านมา โดยบริษัทได้เพิ่ม Bitcoin มูลค่าประมาณ 451 ล้านดอลลาร์ในไตรมาสที่ 4 ปี 2025 ทำให้ครองครองรวมทั้งหมด 35,102 BTC อย่างไรก็ตาม บริษัทกำลังเผชิญกับการขาดทุนยังไม่เกิดจริงที่สำคัญเนื่องจากราคาซื้อเฉลี่ยที่สูง เมื่อ Bitcoin มีราคาอยู่ที่ราว 60,000 ดอลลาร์ ในขณะที่ราคาซื้อเฉลี่ยของ Metaplanet อยู่ที่ 107,716 ดอลลาร์ ทำให้บริษัทอยู่ในภาวะขาดทุนเกือบ 39% เพื่อเสริมสร้างทุนสำรอง บริษัทวางแผนระดมทุนถึง 137 ล้านดอลลาร์ผ่านการจำหน่ายหุ้น ซึ่งส่งผลให้ราคาหุ้นร่วงลงเมื่อเทียบกับความผันผวนในตลาดที่กระทบต่อผู้ถือหุ้นรายใหญ่อย่าง Strategy

EN

Japan’s Metaplanet has reaffirmed its commitment to accumulating Bitcoin despite a severe market downturn that has negatively impacted its stock price. CEO Simon Gerovich stated that the company will continue to purchase the flagship cryptocurrency and expand revenue, even as its shares have plummeted over 63% in the last six months. The firm added roughly $451 million worth of Bitcoin in Q4 2025, bringing its total holdings to 35,102 BTC. However, the company is currently facing significant unrealized losses due to its high average acquisition cost. With Bitcoin trading around $60,000 and Metaplanet's average buying price sitting at $107,716, the firm is underwater by nearly 39%. To bolster its reserves, Metaplanet plans to raise up to $137 million through stock offerings, a move that has further pressured its share price amidst broader market volatility affecting major corporate holders like Strategy.

Article

Japan’s Metaplanet will continue buying Bitcoin even as the crypto market downturn has weighed heavily on the company’s shares. Summary Metaplanet said it will continue accumulating Bitcoin despite a sharp market selloff that has pushed its shares down more than 63% over the past 6 months. The firm added roughly $451 million worth of Bitcoin in Q4 2025, lifting total holdings to 35,102 BTC. As Bitcoin price touched $60,000 around the Asia open, Metaplanet CEO Simon Gerovich took to X to reaffirm the company’s decision to continue stockpiling the flagship cryptocurrency. “We are fully aware that, given the recent stock price trends, our shareholders continue to face a challenging situation,” Gerovich wrote , before adding that the current market scenario will not affect Metaplanet’s Bitcoin buying strategy. “We will steadily continue to accumulate Bitcoin, expand revenue, and prepare for the next phase of growth,” Gerovich said. Metaplanet shares were down over 6% at the time of writing after falling from the day’s open. Losses have been more prominent over the past six months, with the stock dropping more than 63.4% over that period. Bitcoin is down over 47% from its all-time high as of press time, but the persistent downturn over the past month did not deter Metaplanet from inflating its reserves . Throughout the last quarter of 2025, Metaplanet acquired roughly $451 million worth of the largest cryptocurrency, which pushed its total holdings to 35,102 BTC. According to data from Bitcoin Treasuries, the company’s average cost of acquisition is around $107,716. That puts the company at an unrealized loss of nearly 39% based on current prices. Top Bitcoin holders unfazed by crash Metaplanet is not the only Bitcoin hoarder that is currently underwater, as Strategy, the largest corporate holder, reported a $12.6 billion net loss for Q4 2025. With an average acquisition cost of $76,052 per BTC, its holdings are also in the red, with losses of over 13%. However, like Gerovich, Strategy CEO Michael Saylor has assured that the company will continue buying Bitcoin and even dismissed fears of liquidation by noting that BTC would have to crash to $8,000 before it becomes a concern. Metaplanet, on the other hand, is gearing up to raise as much as $137 million using a combination of common shares and stock acquisition rights to fatten its reserves and reduce debt. The announcement, however, did not bode well with company shareholders, as the company’s stock fell by over 3.5% on the day.
